name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: There is not a person who can tell me with a straight face that a $7.25 minimum wage from 13 years ago is fair or acceptable, especially given the current rate of inflation. Our workers and families deserve better. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/E5QgJwW1Ry

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Louisiana native Shalanda Young today became the first Black woman to be confirmed as the director of the @WhiteHouse Office of Management and Budget. Congratulations on this historic achievement, Shalanda! You continue to make your home state proud. #LouisianaProud #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Louisiana‚Äôs women deserve equal pay for equal work. That‚Äôs why I am supporting legislation to enact pay transparency. It isn‚Äôt a silver bullet solution, but it‚Äôs a sensible measure that can make a meaningful difference in reducing the gender pay gap. #EqualPayDay #lagov #LaSOTS  https://t.co/dmnFyifbcK

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: As I contemplate the work I want us to accomplish, I‚Äôm drawn to the Beatitudes, including my favorite: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called children of God.   In a world that has too much hatred, strife, and currently war, let us be peacemakers. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/sb4wHHLDZz

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: I‚Äôll leave you with my favorites: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called children of God.   In a world that has too much hatred, strife, and currently war, let us be peacemakers. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/v7GgzsfTi5

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Our time in office is fleeting, but the decisions we make while here will last generations. I‚Äôm asking that we use this time wisely. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: As we enter this session, I want you to reflect on the people of this great state. Our neighbors, as their spirits are broken and they mourn two years of hardships. Our children, with their meek and pure hearts. Our moms, the most merciful and blessed of all. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Those lessons have stayed with me. And as I contemplate the work I want us to accomplish in the last two years of this term, I‚Äôm drawn to Christ‚Äôs Sermon on the Mount and the Beatitudes. You all know them, but here are a few of my favorites‚Ä¶ #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/OnzNhETfmI

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: As I think you all know, my faith is very important to me. It is the foundation that guides me as I strive every day to become a better leader and a better person. Growing up, I believe I had the hardest catechism teacher there was‚Ä¶my mom. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: You know the old saying ‚Äúif these walls could talk‚Äù? Well, these walls DO talk. History remembers what happens in this building. And the issues we spend the most time on signal to the public what we value the most. So I ask: What do you value most? Who do you value most? #LaSOTS  https://t.co/1lTgUpX92N

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Some of the bills being brought up this session do nothing to make lives better. Nothing to continue moving us forward. They only serve to divide us. And frankly, some are reminiscent of a dark past that we should learn from, not relive. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: And so do women. I am also supporting legislation to enact pay transparency. It isn‚Äôt a silver bullet solution, but it‚Äôs a sensible measure that can make a meaningful difference in reducing the gender pay gap and that will benefit families that need it most. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: There is not a person in this room who can tell me with a straight face that a $7.25 minimum wage from 13 years ago is fair or acceptable, especially given the current rate of inflation. Our workers and families deserve better. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Finally, I can‚Äôt leave this podium without yet again making a plea for you to do the right thing and raise the minimum wage and reduce the gender pay gap. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Ultimately, our motivation for advancing clean energy should be preserving the land we are so very blessed to call home so that Louisiana will not be washed away.  #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/Nj4lAvFMCa

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We‚Äôre scheduled to have the first wind lease sale of the Gulf Coast next year. As we see from legislation filed by Reps. Zeringue & Orgeron, there‚Äôs strong interest in wind energy development. This is the future. We can either get on board or get left behind. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Additionally, combating climate change is just as much about economic development as it is about anything else. Some of our biggest economic development projects recently have been with companies focused on clean energy. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/xubi0tcfRx

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: What makes our plan special is that instead of working against oil and gas companies, we are working with them. In fact, many oil companies have pledged to reach similar net zero goals. We can‚Äôt be more pro-oil and gas than the oil and gas companies. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: That‚Äôs why I established the Climate Initiatives Task Force and set a goal of reaching net zero by 2050. This task force, which includes scientists, academics, industry leaders and environmentalists, has adopted a Statewide Climate Action Plan. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We are all having to adapt to a changing environment ‚Äì one where storms are getting stronger and more frequent. We don‚Äôt get to dictate when the next storm hits or how bad it‚Äôs going to be. But we can work to mitigate the impacts of climate change. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Insurance is a wonderful thing ‚Äì when it functions as intended. Unfortunately, companies don‚Äôt always work in good faith with homeowners. All we‚Äôre asking is that they play by the rules. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: My agenda includes bills focused on hurricane deductibles, claim transparency, enforcing insurance fraud laws, revamping the adjuster registry so policyholders can verify adjusters, & stopping mortgage companies from withholding insurance money without good reason. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Vineyard Christian Fellowship Church of Lake Charles has endured a similar story. Co-Pastor George Rodrigues wasn‚Äôt able to get the insurance benefits the church was entitled to until last summer. The church‚Äôs facilities still aren‚Äôt back to 100%. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Pat‚Äôs of Henderson is an iconic seafood restaurant in Lake Charles. The day after Hurricane Laura made landfall, owner Nick Perioux hired a contractor so he could get the restaurant open. Instead, he struggled with his insurance company until November of last year. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Unfortunately, Kerry and Peggy are far from the only ones left in insurance purgatory. There are thousands of other families and business owners as well who have been left in the lurch. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: In Southeast Louisiana, Peggy Honore, who teaches at LSU‚Äôs School of Public Health, had FIVE insurance adjusters in just the first twelve weeks after Ida destroyed her home in Destrehan. How is that even remotely possible or acceptable? #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Kerry is also a breast cancer patient. Her sole focus right now should be on fighting cancer, not fighting with her insurance company. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Kerry Anderson has a historic home that was destroyed by Hurricanes Laura and Delta. After 18 months, she is still battling her insurance company to force them to pay even a fraction of what she is owed. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It's also unacceptable that many residents are more scared of their insurance companies than the storm itself. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/099omQCARo

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Suffering damage due to a natural disaster is life-altering. And yet, there are landlords who used it for a cash grab. I am supporting legislation by Rep. Landry that has bipartisan support, which will strengthen tenant protections in the aftermath of a disaster. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Let‚Äôs be clear though - it‚Äôs not just a federal problem. Recent disasters have exposed the unacceptable ways our neighbors are being taken advantage of when they are at their most vulnerable. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The federal government hasn‚Äôt allocated sufficient funds for Hurricanes Laura, Delta, & Ida. It‚Äôs a damn shame. When I talk to people in DC, they tell me more aid is coming and I believe it will, but I don‚Äôt blame folks for feeling like they‚Äôve been left behind. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Another system that is broken is the way our citizens are treated in the aftermath of a natural disaster, which unfortunately here in Louisiana happens way too often. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: I‚Äôll support bills that do just that, including a bill to clarify the criminal law of malfeasance in office to apply to constitutional civil rights violations & provide for revocation of POST certification if an officer is found to have committed such an offense. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: I mentioned the proposed increase in supplemental pay for law enforcement officers. Part of that effort needs to be ensuring that those officers can have the trust of the public. We need to do more to hold the very few officers who violate that trust accountable. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Having personally witnessed redistricting twice now, I can say that the current process is not working as intended. That's why I am supporting legislation to establish an independent redistricting commission to support the Legislature for future redistricting. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Our children are watching us. Many took part in the process to make their voices heard, pleading that the right thing be done. We must think beyond ourselves and focus on their future, the future of our state, and the place they want to continue to call home. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The African American voting age population in this state is 31.2 %. And it‚Äôs likely more because according to a report by the Census Bureau, the Black population was undercounted. We shouldn't need a court to tell us how to do basic math: One third of six is two. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The Legislature undertook 5 separate redistricting efforts. A total of 163 districts. And across those 5 bills and 163 districts there‚Äôs not one net new majority Black district anywhere. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The most egregious in my view is the Congressional map because there are half as many majority minority districts as the law, basic fairness and I believe basic math require. Therefore, I vetoed the Congressional bill. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The current demographic makeup of our state shows that the African American population has grown over the last 10 years and yet, while numerous maps were filed reflecting this growth, none of these maps made it to my desk. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It is disappointing and unfortunate, in my view, that the end result of the special session did not reflect what is right and fair and what is required by the Voting Rights Act. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: As I‚Äôve said: the voters should be choosing their leaders; leaders should not be picking and choosing their voters. Partisanship & self-interest cannot rule the day. Voting is one of the most important and cherished rights and responsibilities of ALL Americans. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/XUIfHxmu86

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The rest of my legislative package is also about transforming our future for the people of our state. That includes ensuring that the citizens of this state are fairly represented. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: That‚Äôs why my administration worked closely with Rep. Deshotel to create the Granting Unserved Municipalities Broadband Opportunities grant program. This program will provide grants for broadband infrastructure, connecting more than 471,000 unserved residents. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: A strong internet structure is essential to economic competitiveness, access to healthcare, educational opportunities, and an overall better quality of life. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It‚Äôs also with a focus on the future that we are working to eliminate the digital divide ‚Äì a goal I have set to accomplish by 2029. Internet is something most of us take for granted. But there are too many Louisianans who still don‚Äôt have access. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We are not going back to the days of deficits, fiscal cliffs and one-time dollars for recurring expenditures. And we will continue to be focused on empowering families and communities for the future. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: This is a balanced budget that is responsible, transformational, and continues my administration‚Äôs practice of only using one-time dollars for one-time expenses. It‚Äôs a promise I made six years ago and one that I have not deviated from. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Some folks may ask why this is a priority. Our businesses are still recovering from the pandemic. If we don‚Äôt replenish the trust fund, it will automatically trigger an increase in taxes on businesses in the state ‚Äì big and small, which pay into the trust fund.  #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: My budget proposal also dedicates $550 million in federal American Rescue Plan funding to replenish Louisiana‚Äôs Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund, which had been funded at historically high levels prior to the pandemic. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We‚Äôve made significant progress, but the funds we are receiving from the federal government will allow us to catapult big ticket projects from talk to action. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We‚Äôre all tired of the jokes about knowing you‚Äôve entered Louisiana when the roads get bad.  Since becoming governor, we‚Äôve invested nearly $4.7 billion in projects, including 6,312 miles of our highways, in order to change that narrative. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: My proposal includes more than $1.1 billion in funding for critical infrastructure, such as $500 million for a new Mississippi River Bridge in Baton Rouge, an additional $100 million for the Lake Charles bridge and $500 million for water and sewer improvements. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/DedE0ug9gc

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: With funds from the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, the American Rescue Plan, and our normal Capital Outlay program, we will make meaningful progress on Mega-projects and deferred maintenance projects that have been sitting on a shelf for decades. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Most notably, we are going to invest in infrastructure unlike any time in our history. Roads, bridges, ports, railways, water and sewage systems, orphan wells, and broadband. They all need our attention. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: The items I‚Äôve mentioned so far are recurring expenditures. But we also have a momentous opportunity this year to commit one-time dollars to one-time expenses. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We can never adequately compensate the men and women who put their lives on the line for public safety. However, it is important that we have the ability to recruit, train, and retain the best in law enforcement. They deserve it. And the public deserves it. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We are also including a $100 per month supplemental pay increase for eligible first responders, which includes law enforcement officers and firefighters. Here in Louisiana, we need to put to rest this talk about defunding the police. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: There are many direct support workers like Sheliaka who understand how important their jobs are and want to stay. But at the end of the day, they have to be able to pay their bills. They deserve more than this raise, but I hope it can be a step towards change. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: But that hasn‚Äôt stopped Sheliaka Harvey who is a certified health manager and direct service worker at Terrebone Arc in Houma. She helps take care of 6 women. She says she cares for them as if they are her own family and seeing them smile makes her day. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: My budget also includes a $12 per diem increase for intermediate care facilities for people living with intellectual disabilities. The funding will be used to support Direct Service Workers in the medical field. The pay is too low and the work is difficult. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It is the least we can do for the people who never gave up on our students despite unprecedented circumstances, and it continues our goal of getting teacher pay up to at least the Southern Regional Average. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: However, I believe we can do even better. That‚Äôs why I am recommending that the first $50 million of any increase in the revenue forecast that the REC may recognize before the budget is passed go to increasing teacher raises to $2,000. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Shaping the future always, always begins with education. The budget I have proposed includes investments at every level. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/6Tfc041tb6

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We have a once in a generation opportunity to shape our future, and we must take advantage of it. It is not an exaggeration to say that the choices that will be made this session will have a lasting legacy for the state. We have to get this right. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It adds up to a historic opportunity to transform our state through investments in education, infrastructure projects that have been pipe dreams, long overdue pay raises for some of our most dedicated workers, and combating the effects of climate change. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Today, as I stand here before you, we have hundreds of millions in surplus, even more in current year excess, and billions in federal funding through the American Rescue Plan and the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We are also in a much better place today than we were six years ago. At my first state of the state, I had just inherited a billion-dollar budget deficit to close out that fiscal year, and a two-billion-dollar deficit for the year that started July 1, 2016. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: That is in large part due to healthcare heroes around the state and the stalwart team at @LADeptHealth, including State Health Officer Dr. Joe Kanter and Secretary Dr. Courtney Phillips. They may be weary, but they have not wavered in their efforts to save lives. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: I don‚Äôt know what the future holds, but I do know that we are in a much better place today than we were two years ago. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Just because the proclamation is expiring doesn‚Äôt mean COVID is over. If the circumstances call for it, I will not hesitate to declare another emergency. But God willing, we will never have to see such difficult mitigation measures in our state again. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: This decision was certainly not made lightly. I have met with the Division of Administration, @GOHSEP, @LADeptHealth, and @LANationalGuard to ensure that there will be no federal aid repercussions or other adverse consequences from not renewing the proclamation. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: On March 11, 2020 I signed a public health emergency for COVID-19. And while it changed to reflect the ebb and flow of the pandemic, it has remained in effect since then. This Wednesday, the order expires. And after 24 months, I will not be renewing it. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/rOTc9yuSe8

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Cases and hospitalizations have been steadily dropping since we emerged from the Omicron fueled surge this winter. Parades rolled again this Mardi Gras. If that‚Äôs not a Louisiana breeze of hope, I don‚Äôt know what is. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: But a lot has changed since this time two years ago. We have safe and effective vaccines that are saving countless lives. We have better therapeutic treatments. High-quality masks are now a practical option for families. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: It was exactly two years ago today that we marked the first death from COVID-19 in Louisiana. Since then, over 16,800 Louisianans have died, and more than 1.2 million cases have been confirmed. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Like me, I know that many of you have sacrificed seeing loved ones in order to keep them safe. And unfortunately, we‚Äôve all lost people dear to us because of COVID-19. We‚Äôve lost people who should be in this room with us now. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: We‚Äôve been through a lot over these past two years. I‚Äôve always been one to count my blessings, but now I cherish the time spent with loved ones even more‚Äì especially my children ‚Äì Samantha Bel, Sarah Ellen, & John Miller. My beautiful wife, @FirstLadyofLA. #LaSOTS #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, members of the Legislature and my fellow Louisianans. It is an honor to be back in this chamber after delivering last year‚Äôs speech offsite due to COVID. #LaSOTS #lagov  https://t.co/7r0P44P1Yj

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: This is an extension of Louisiana‚Äôs ongoing efforts in diversifying the makeup of our energy sources and ensuring an economically and environmentally balanced approach to cleaner use of traditional fuels and transition to new potential energy sources. #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: Louisiana, as well as our partner states, have a long history of producing and transporting fuels and feedstocks in liquid and gas forms, as well as significant population of industrial end users with potential to use hydrogen as fuel or as part of manufacturing processes. #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
tweet: In entering the agreement, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Arkansas intend to compete as a unit for funding established in the Infrastructure, Investment, and Jobs Act (IIJA) of 2021, in which @ENERGY is directed to seek out and select regional clean hydrogen hubs to fund. #lagov

name: John Bel Edwards
